original_title: Sri Lanka to change EPF Act to assure 9% return after DDR
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s cabinet had approved a proposal by President Ranil Wickremesighe to amend the Employees Provident Fund law to assure a 9 percent annual return after a domestic debt restructure Minister Bandula Gunawardana said.
The 9 percent return which will apply for the 2023-2026 period was arrived at after considering the returns over the past five years.
The Employee’s Provident Fund is the largest retirement fund of private sector workers, which is managed by the state.
Sri Lanka has to extend the maturity of domestic debt to meet an International Monetary Fund request ceiling on annual rollovers of debt.
“The EPF holders can withdraw their funds at retirement,” Gunawardana said. “The amendment will guarantee a 9 percent return.”
Trade union activists have protested the restructuring of debt, which is may reduce the returns for the EPF with at least two groups seeking relief from courts.
However calculating returns also involves projecting future interest rates. (Colombo/Aug09/2023)
